sen.j: 町衆（まちしゅう/ちょうしゅう）とは、室町時代から戦国時代 (日本)にかけての、特に土倉などの京都の裕福な商工業者である。
sen.e: Machi-shu was a class consisting of wealthy commercial and industrial men, including doso (pawnbrokers and moneylenders), in Kyoto from the Muromachi period to Sengoku period (period of warring states) in Japan.

Machi-shu was a class consisting of wealthy commercial and industrial men, including doso (pawnbrokers and moneylenders), in Kyoto from the Muromachi period to the Sengoku period (period of warring states) in Japan.

Machi-shu (also known as Cho-shu) was a class consisting of wealthy commercial and industrial men, including doso (pawnbrokers and moneylenders), in Kyoto from the Muromachi period to the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) in Japan.
sen.cmt: 別読みを補足しました。

sen.j: 応仁の乱後の京都復興においての重要な階層である。
sen.e: This class played an important role in Kyoto reconstruction after the Onin war.
sen.cmt: C列の単語調査に「階層 - hierarchy」とありますが、hierarchyは階層構造そのものを指すような気がしますので、ここではclassとしました。

sen.j: 平安時代の京童などを継承する概念で近世、江戸時代の町人へと継承される。
sen.e: Representing a concept that inherited "Kyoto's young people" and the like in the Heian period, "Machi-shu" was to be evolved into "townspeople" in the early-modern and Edo period.

Representing a concept that inherited Kyowarabe (Kyoto's young people) and the like in the Heian period, Machi-shu was to be evolved into Chonin (townspeople) in the early-modern and Edo periods.

sen.j: 今日では「まちしゅう」と読まれることが多いが、『節要集』『日葡辞書』などの同時代史料によれば「ちょうしゅう」と発音されていたようである。
sen.e: Although it is mostly read 'Machi-shu' today, it was apparently read 'choushu' according to the historical materials in that period including "Setsuyo-shu"(a book on oriental medicine written by Waichi SUGIYAMA in the 1610s) and "Vocabvlario da Lingoa de Iapam" (Japanese-Portuguese dictionary, published 1603-1604).
